Name: Mercator
Description: Mercator is a business and trading game for 2 to 6 players. The board is a copy of the map of the world of the geographer Strabon (60 B.C. - 25 A.D.) and encloses the Orbis Romanum (the Roman world) which agrees historically with the Roman empire in the first and second century. The game uses ideas ahead of its time for trading, development, land management, and political maneuvering.

Name: Desert Dice
Description: A unique dice dexterity game that uses a large wooden frame holding real sand. Dice of various sizes are buried in the sand, and players use magnetic rods to pull up dice of specific values to score points.

Name: Regenbogen
Description: Regenbogen (Rainbow) is a large box filled with cards of many colors. With these cards, players build structures to score points. The taller, more complex, and more colors used, the more the points.

Name: Vectorace
Description:
From the instructions:
Four races of beings from different areas of the galaxy are faced with extinction. They are each involved in the desperate search for a new solar system.
The elders of each race have summoned their top space pilots to head the mission to secure their new home.
Each player takes on one of these journeys into space in the hope of being the first to guarantee survival.
"Only one race can survive".

The board represents a galaxy which consists of 16 solar systems - four dying and twelve unexplored. The gameboard is laminated so that the planet counters, made of shiny flexible plastic, can adhere to the board during play, but are easily peeled off and re-positioned. It has a 70 sci-fi look, and ‘3d’ energy recording strips which are exchanged when alliances are formed. 
Interlocking ships are used to move round the board to colonize planets, gain energy points and split apart for combat. Movement is by dice, though players can elect to slow the ship down by using energy points, to enable them to reach specific target squares. Hyperspace Gates can also be used to perform more complex moves. Combat is resolved by a highest dice wins system. An Asteroid belt finalizes a range of encounters, from combat to entering an occupied square. There are also rules for alliances and planet hopping.

Name: Flag To Flag Racing
Description:
A very straight-forward racing game.  Players roll dice to move their cars around a track separated into spaces.  Some spaces are cautions, at which a caution card is drawn.  Players gain and lose money throughout the race and receive bonus money based on finishing positions.  Multiple races can be played.  The player with the most money at the end wins the game.

Components include board, custom money, caution cards, dice and playing piece cars.

The game looks to be self-published, with the box stating "Limited 1st Edition," and the rules stating that "You have purchased one of the original 2500 games produced."  I doubt that there was a second run.

Rules also state: "Copyright No. VA249-950 Flag To Flag Racing Game. September 21, 1992" and "Made in North Carolina U.S.A."

Name: Picture Bingo
Description:
Picture Bingo is a perception game for 1-3 children. A leader should be chosen before each game. The leader selects one picture tile after the other and says its name out loud. If a player finds that tile on their picture board they get to keep that tile and place it on their board. The first player to fill their picture board wins.

Source: Amazon.com

Name: Numero
Description: A tile matching game to learn to count. Learn amounts and numbers from one to ten.

Name: Plumino
Description: Mathematical brains, this is for you! With correct addition or subtraction, you can exchange your game pieces on the flower. Exciting reckoning using 1-10 made easy.

Name: Piccobello
Description: There is a washing basket full of sparkling clean wash, waiting to be hung out to dry for each player. The trouble is, they can only hang out the item whose color is shown by the dice. Typical, though, the weather doesn't always do what it should. The wash only dries properly when it is sunny and windy. If it rains, the wash must be taken down and put in the basket again.

Name: Venga-Venga!
Description: "Oh no, the vet is due a visit! We'd better run away." The cow, horse, dog, and other animals need their check-up to make sure they get through winter safely. Help the farmer to catch his stray animals. An exciting dice game that is cunning, tricky, and needing a little bit of luck. The winner is the player with four stamps in his health certificate.

Name: Tunelino
Description: The travelers on the train are going on a long journey today. First of all, the train must be hooked together. The reward for being a successful engineer is to ride through the tunnel.

Name: Catch the Animals
Description: Six popular pets are in the middle of the table as cards. The same six pets are on the sides of the four dice. Who will be the first to find the animals shown by the dice? Players have to react quick as a flash and grab the right cards!

Name: Colorful Ottokar
Description: Each player tries to be the first to thread his disks onto Ottokar the Octopus. The one who does this most quickly wins.

Name: Loco-Motifs
Description: Real railway tracks emerge from each of the eight-track cards when the correct motifs on the reverse side are uncovered. Which locomotive will be the first to the finish and ring the winner's bell?

Name: Fädelmaus
Description: The children are excited -- a mouse darts through the nursery and the garden. It has already slipped through seven holes -- who can best thread the mouse's path?

Name: Pillow Pincher
Description:
To sleep peacefully, each dwarf needs its own matching pillow. But a pillow pincher causes unrest by stealing pillows again and again. With a bit of luck on the dice, one can take the pillows back from the pincher and cover up his dwarf.

Ages 3 and up.

Name: Fädelraupe
Description:
The caterpillar grows with each little disk. Thread correctly, and learn to distinguish colors while playing.

Ages 3 and up.

Name: Greif zu!: Würfeln, schauen, schnappen
Description: Act quickly in Greif zu!: Würfeln, schauen, schnappen as this lively game is about snapping up the pictures that have just been rolled on the dice. The player who reacts the fastest wins the game.

Name: Fantasto
Description: Feeling, touching, and finding the right colors: who will fetch the right token out of the little pouch? The tokens have to be plugged into the picture board matching both is size and color.

Name: Scolina
Description: An entertaining learning game with a built-in key to check the solutions to problems. Learning by playing is fun: find the pairs, sort the shapes and colors, and put things in order.

Name: Sparito!
Description:
The baby animals make the most of the lovely weather by going on an outing in the forest. Some of the little animals play hide and seek. See if you can find out who is missing! Nominated for Kinder Spiel des Jahres in 2003.

To play you take the 16 animal tiles and set 3 aside.  You then flip through the remaining tiles, calling out their names or making the animal sounds for extra fun.  Then mark on your score board which animals were set aside.  It's a memory game, so your kids will beat you handily.

Includes 16 sturdy cardboard animal tiles, 4 wooden scoreboards and 12 wooden marking disks.

Name: Popsicle Zone Games
Description: Three games in one. Game one: the coolest hoppin' Popsicle party ever! Collect the most Popsicles. Game two: The Popsicle 500 race game. Get in gear and hurry around the game board. Game three: Popsicle or President? To win the election, get out there and collect votes!

Name: Ein Mops kommt selten allein!
Description: Four pugs go to eat, but one is not who they seem! Dash as quickly as possible to the food but be careful to get enough to eat else lose your place.

Name: Colorloc
Description:
From the rule sheet:

Colorloc is a game for 2 players.  Each player has 23 pieces.  The pieces are of three types: colored, grey or plain.  Each player has 16 colored pieces, 6 grey pieces and 1 plain piece.  Whites plain piece is solid white.  Blacks plain piece is solid black.

The object of the game is to capture your opponents plain (target) piece.

The basic premise of the game is that a colored piece is locked into lines of it's own color and the black lines.  Each piece has it's own special rules to follow in addition to this.  Grey pieces can move on any line, and the grey 'dot' pieces are particularly powerful..

Name: Trigammon
Description:
Backgammon for 2 to 6!

In a 3 player game: Each player has 15 “stones”. These stones are played from the slots and are brought onto the “Bear In Table” according to dice rolls.

The object of Trigammon is to move your stones from the slots to the “Bear In Table” then around the game board to the “Bear Out Table” and then off before your opponents can.

There are variations for 2 to 6 players.

Name: It's a Knockout
Description:
Based on the hit BBC television program of the same name, 'It's a Knockout', versions of which ran concurrently in countries across Europe.  Contestants competed in silly obstacle course type games, usually wearing equally silly costumes.  Regional heats culminated in the winners representing their countries in international contests known as "Jeux Sans Frontières" (Games Without Frontiers).  The board game was originally created in Britain in 1974 and became the Australian Toy Association's game of the year in 1986.

Players move around a playing board until they land on one of the 'games' that include variants on tiddlywinks, target shooting, blow football and bowling. The position that players finish in the sub-games determines the amount of points that they receive.  Each player has a "joker" that can be played before any one game and they get double points for that game.

The player with the highest number of points wins.

The game is designed for children, but is enjoyable when played by adults that remember the television program.

Name: Sterneföifi
Description: A planetarium-themed game where players must identify constellations and other sky objects. The game includes 9 different start disks and components to make it competitive.

Name: Atrio
Description:
Atrio is played on an octagon with 3 marbles per player. Pieces are pushed away by playing a dark marble. The first player who gets his marbles in the inner circle or who ousts one of the opponent's marbles off the board (beyond the large circle) wins

Atrio was designed by Christian Gibon (France) and first published in 1997 by  LM Créations.

Rules: http://maisonauteursdejeu.free.fr/Site.MAJ/LesJeux/ATRIO/Presentation.htm

Name: Die Sonnenflieger
Description: The sun stands in the center of the board surrounded by the universe. Each player tries to reach the sun in order to obtain eternal life! The goal of the game is to become old and to live out a happy life.  Players reach the sun using basic elements like air, fire, and and water, and the more trips made the higher the score.

Name: Kopf an Kopf
Description: An eye feast for the culturally interested. The game idea is traditional memory matching. The 80 cards show costumes as well as photos of statues, sculptures and paintings.  Beautiful, fascinating photos of different time epochs come from the Rietberg Museum in Zurich.  An accompanying booklet gives information about all of the photos.

Name: Buurejahr
Description: Two pleasant cube games.  For gamers:  Manage the farm most efficiently to make the most money.  For children:  Cultivate, harvest, and experience seasons and play the activities on the farm as a Cooperative game with many rewards in between.

Name: Mindstalkers
Description:
From their website

Mindstalkers is a skirmish wargame. The game starts in the distant future of mankind, but the actual action will be set in various historical ages.

The first line of miniatures and rule sets (in production right now and named "Mission: Middle Ages") regards the Italian Middle Ages (14th - 15th centuries). The following rule sets will be created according to the preferences of players themselves. New rules will be introduced for different historical ages: from the naval battles between pirates, to remote future wars, passing through barbarian invasions and the two World Wars... all will be possible!

The core rule set is based on fantasy/science fiction, but the game system allows the use of two different levels of rules.

The first one is purely historical, no fantasy or sci-fi elements, designed to play a true historical skirmish wargame: rules, equipment and characters are all strictly based on the referenced age. The second level provides special rules for fantasy elements (like psionic powers), according to the plot of Mindstalkers and adding unforeseeable features and fun to the skirmishes, but always keeping the fighting realism high.

Name: Tempora
Description: Tempora is a game about moving through different times.  How have people experienced different cultures and lives during different times? "You have the clocks, we have the time": this African sentence was made at the address of Europeans and this inspired the game. A game with clocks and beautiful pictures from all over the world.

Name: Das Bus Spiel
Description: A game with large wooden pieces representing buses.  The game is played on the floor. The "board" is the whole room. The buses go from stop to stop, and the winner is the player who can first deliver three multi colored passengers to their destination.

Name: Trollig
Description: The trolls have robbed the king's treasure and are holding it under a spell. Whoever uses his skill to strike the stone tiles with the magic stick can flip them face up and reveal a part of the valuable treasure. But watch out: if a Troll appears on a tile the magic in your stick is lost and your turn ends!

Name: Kuller Spass
Description:
The animals are hungry and are anxious to be fed with the fruits of the magic tree. But be careful: Only the one who shows some skill in this marble game will be able to hit the right fruits with the rolling ball and thus put aside his cards. Two game variants with different degrees of difficulty.

Ages 5 and up.

Name: Wer Machts Wie
Description: This game, which translates as "Who Does it How?", is the very evil twin to the Zoch game Who Lives Where. Like its child-game brother, this game includes very nicely carved small houses with animals laser cut from their bases. The trick in this game, however, is that instead of friendly crocodiles, pigs, and others trying to find the right home, this game is all about pigs in a variety of "romantic" positions. Some will make you blush, others are down-right X-rated. The Zoch team at Essen chuckle at this game and say that is a favorite gift for wedding showers.

Name: Golden Trivia
Description:
The game consists of 999 Question & Answer cards with 5 questions on each card. Upon each card are 5 dice symbols (1 dot through 5 dots.)

A roll of the die determines which question will be asked (by the player to the right of the answerer). If the answerer fails to answer the question, the question is passed to the player to the left and so on but excluding the questioner.

On a roll of 6, the player misses their turn. On a correct answer, the answerer earns points and the turn is over.

Players play to an agreed upon score.

The game also features a gang-up on the leader mechanic, potentially prolonging the torture for everyone. :)

Name: Whales
Description:
Whales is a two player (or two team) game with a very simple dice rolling mechanic. Players will either play on the Toothed (red) whale team or the Baleen (yellow) whale team.

The playing board shows eight whales, four of each type. Upon the whales are several circles, with numbers ranging from 2 to 12 (2d6 possibilities). The teams take turns rolling two dice and placing red or yellow colored 'barnacles' upon available circles. On dice rolls of 5 or 10, the Special Cards deck is used. On dice rolls of doubles, another turn is taken.

The Special Cards deck contains cards with educational information on whales and an action, such as placing a barnacle in an available circle on one of your whales.

The round ends when one team has filled all four of their whales with barnacles. Points, bonuses and penalties are scored, then another round is begun. The game is played in several rounds until one side has scored the desired number of points.

Name: Sapperlot
Description:
Ingenuity and vocabulary are required in this game.  The players note as many words as possible with a specific letters drawn. But think quickly - then the time runs out....

The game is in German but works just as well in English.

Name: Politiskt korrekt?
Description: Politiskt korrekt? is a Swedish game produced by the market liberal think tank Timbro. It is a light hearted trivia card game highlighting economic and political facts combined with a bit of humor.

Name: Flickers!
Description:
Flickers! is the first game of the Canadian-owned company Eagle Games Ltd. From their website:

Flickers!, the movie trivia game that leaves nothing to chance!

Flickers (slang):  a motion picture.

That explains the name of the game. But why do we call it the movie trivia game that leaves nothing to chance? Because in this game,  the element of chance has been eliminated.  There are no traditional dice to indicate space moves on aboard; there are no exact number requirements to win the game and there are no free rolls of a dice.

The only playing piece is a color-coded cube corresponding to movie categories.

Flickers! is scored, and won, solely on your knowledge of the movies.  You score points (or lose them) based on what you know about the movies, from home-grown fare to foreign treats, from the 1930s to the present.

Flickers! has been created and designed to be fun for the casual once-a-month movie goer as well as challenging enough for the avid movie-a-week film buff.

Flickers! can be played by any number of adult players, anytime, anywhere.  It can be played by individuals, or in teams. It can be played at the dining-room table,  in the park, or in the back seat  of a car on a road trip.

And if any of the question and answer cards pique your curiosity, go out and rent the movie. You may have no idea what delights you are missing when you don't explore all the genres from all the decades, and the works of stars past and present.

Above all, enjoy.....the movies and Flickers!

Name: Crossfire
Description:
Inspired by Sid Sackson's classic abstract Focus, Crossfire is a stacking game played on a hexagonal grid.

Piece stacks have a maximum size dependent on how many neighboring hexes it has. Excess pieces in a stack are removed from the bottom by the stack's controller and either returned to the stack controller's reserve to return to the board later, or else are captured and removed from the game.

A move consists of a player moving either a stack he controls, or pieces from the top of a stack he controls, and then moves those pieces in a straight line a number of spaces up to the number of pieces being moved. Alternatively, a player may introduce a piece from his reserve onto any space on the board.

The game is won when he forces his opponent into a position where his opponent cannot make a move.

Name: HexDame
Description:
HexDame translates International Draughts onto a hexagonal grid (or, alternatively, onto the vertices' of a triangular grid). Pieces move either straight ahead or in either forward-oblique direction.

Board of HexDame

          .
        .   .
      .   .   .
    .   .   .   .
  .   .   .   .   .
 9  .   .   .   .  i
  .   .   .   .   .
 8  .   .   .   .  h
  .   .   .   .   .
 7  .   .   .   .  g
  .   .   .   .   .
 6  .   .   .   .  f
  .   .   .   .   .
 5  .   .   .   .  e
   4  .   .   .  d
     3  .   .  c
       2  .  b
         1 a


Initial setting with sixteen red men (r) and sixteen white men (w)


          r
        r   r
      r   r   r
    r   r   r   r
  .   r   r   r   .
 9  .   r   r   .  i
  .   .   r   .   .
 8  .   .   .   .  h
  .   .   .   .   .
 7  .   .   .   .  g
  .   .   w   .   .
 6  .   w   w   .  f
  .   w   w   w   .
 5  w   w   w   w  e
   4  w   w   w  d
     3  w   w  c
       2  w  b
         1 a



     Game play alternates between player white and player red.
     Player white begins.
     Players are not allowed to skip a turn.


				
				
					Objective
     A player wins by capturing all opponent's pieces or if the opponent can not perform a legal move on his turn.
     On agreement or if the same game situation repeats three times the game is draw.


				
				
					Moving
     Men move forward only. Thus following the algebraic notation of the diagram
         red men move either
             in direction of smaller numbers or
             preceeding letters (alphabetical order) or
             both at once, while
        
         white men move either
             in direction of higher numbers or
             suceeding letters or
             both at once.
        
    


Sample moves: Red man can move to positions indicated by '#', while white man can move to '+'

          .
        .   .
      .   .   .
    .   .   .   .
  .   .   .   .   .
 9  .   .   .   .  i
  .   r   .   .   .
 8  #   #   .   .  h
  .   #   .   .   .
 7  .   .   +   .  g
  .   .   +   +   .
 6  .   .   w   .  f
  .   .   .   .   .
 5  .   .   .   .  e
   4  .   .   .  d
     3  .   .  c
       2  .  b
         1 a


				
				
					Promotion to King
     On reaching the rows at the opposite edge of the board at conclusion of a move it promotes to king. This is indicated by stacking a second checker of same color on top. In order to promote, a man must end its move on a square of the back rank. If a man, in the course of a capture, visits a cell of the back rank without ending its move on it, it does not promote!


Red men get promoted when reaching any of the nine positions indicated '#' at conclusion of red's move.
White men get promoted when reaching any of the nine positions indicated '+' at conclusion of white's move.


          +
        +   +
      +   .   +
    +   .   .   +
  +   .   .   .   +
 9  .   .   .   .  i
  .   .   .   .   .
 8  .   .   .   .  h
  .   .   .   .   .
 7  .   .   .   .  g
  .   .   .   .   .
 6  .   .   .   .  f
  #   .   .   .   #
 5  #   .   .   #  e
   4  #   .   #  d
     3  #   #  c
       2  #  b
         1 a



     Thus
         the last rows at the edge of the board for white consists of fields from e9 to i9 followed by i9 to i5, while
         the last rows at the edge of the board for red consists of fields from a5 to a1 followed by a1 to e1.
    


				
				
					Capturing
     Men can capture an adjacent opponent's piece (man or king) by jumping over it following a straight line onto the empty field directly behind the opponent's piece.
     Capturing is compulsory, including making chained jumps if available. Thus men's turn may consist in chained jumps. 
     If more than one capture move is available in a player's turn then it is obligatory to select the capturing move resulting in capturing the maximum amount of the opponent's pieces (men or kings).
     If optional chained capturing might capture same amount, the player may choose.
     Men are non flying. Thus they can only capture an opponent's piece adjacent to their own position. 
     Kings are flying. They may move over any amount of empty fields or capture a piece in any amount of empty fields' distance away as long as the adjacent field behind the captured piece is empty. Anyway if a king captures, it may land on any empty field immediately behind or following empty fields in straight line of the captured piece unless it is required to stop on a specific field in order to continue jumping according to the rule of capturing maximum amount of opponent's pieces.
     Any capture move may be performed by men or kings in any direction - forwards or backwards.
     Each jump is performed in a straight line over any single opponent's piece. The adjacent field behind the pieces captured must be free.
     A possible chained jump can consist of single jumps having a combination of same or even different directions.
     In a chained capture move opponent's pieces are removed only after capturing is complete.
     During a chained capture a piece may not be jumped more than once. But it is allowed to revisit or jump over any empty field multiple times then.
     There is no breezing as a penalty for captures that are not performed.

Name: Mach Speed Hunters
Description:
Mach Speed Hunters 
Aerial Combat in the Modern Age
35 page PDF

Mach Speed Hunters is a complete miniatures game of air combat in the missile-armed Modern era. The basic rules allow for relatively large battles with up to a dozen aircraft per side and minimal record keeping.

Optional rules are included which cover; air to ground combat, bombers, air-to-ground munitions, variable pilot quality and experience, and simple campaign system.

Advanced rules which add realism include; advanced maneuvering, deflection shooting, advanced air-to-air missiles, countermeasures, visual spotting, limited ammunition, critical damage, and more...

Also included is a missile reference and the Afterburners aircraft lists, with game stats for 118 different aircraft from 12 different nations.

Download version can be purchased at www.wargamedownloads.com

Name: Knights in the Sky
Description:
Knights in the Sky
Aerial Combat in the First World War
31 page PDF

Knights in the Sky is a complete miniatures game of WWI air combat. The basic rules allow for relatively large battles with up to a dozen aircraft per side and minimal record keeping.

Optional rules are included which cover; air to ground combat, bombers, observation balloons, Zeppelins, variable pilot quality and experience, and simple campaign system.

Advanced rules which add realism include; advanced maneuvering, deflection shooting, visual spotting, limited ammunition, critical damage, and more...

Also included is the Canvas Falcons aircraft lists, with game stats for 99 different aircraft from 6 different nations.

Download version can be purchased at www.wargamedownloads.com

Name: MiG Hunters
Description:
MiG Hunters
Aerial Combat in the 1950's
25 page PDF

MiG Hunters is a complete miniatures game of air combat in the transitional era of the 1950's. The basic rules allow for relatively large battles with up to a dozen aircraft per side and minimal record keeping.

Optional rules are included which cover; air to ground combat, bombers, variable pilot quality and experience, and simple campaign system.

Advanced rules which add realism include; advanced maneuvering, deflection shooting, visual spotting, limited ammunition, critical damage, and more...

Also included is the Swept Wings aircraft lists, with game stats for 38 different aircraft from 4 different nations.

Download version can be purchased at www.wargamedownloads.com

Name: Kleine Lok
Description: Where is the steam engine headed? The numbers on the backs of the station cards indicate the distance. Whoever pays attention and has a good memory will turn over the right cards and move the Little Steam Engine a long way. Little lumps of coal are given out as a reward.

Name: Strandhogg
Description:
Subtitled "Viking Age Skirmish Rules," Strandhogg (translation: "Beach Raid") is a set of miniature wargame rules for 25/28mm or 15mm games simulating Viking raids and small battles of the era of the Sagas.

The rules cover Leadership with several categories including Nobles, Jarls, Ealdormen and Lords; Commanders (Huscarls, Thanes and Milites) and troop types including Warriors, Levy, Archers/Slingers/Crossbowmen, Berserkers, and Armed Peasants/Townfolk.

Warbands are composed of various combinations of these types up to an agreed-upon point value; different categories of soldier have differing values, and accessories such as Spears and Shields add to a type's cost.  A Record Sheet is made out with values for each Leader and Warband involved in a game.

Initiative is determine by use of cards from a conventional card deck.  Each player is assigned a card number or suit, adding a card for each Warband under a player's control.  Additional cards can be added to reflect additional events or participants in a given scenario, for example, the random appearance of a traveling Lord or Bishop and retinue.

Dynamics of play involve Morale, Courage, Agility, Terrain, Non-Warband Movement, Shieldwalls and Wedges, the use of ships, and Mounted forces.  Information is provided for Saxons and Normans as well as Vikings, and the system is also adaptable to other peoples with whom the Vikings interacted, including Picts, Arabs or Skraelings (Native Americans) with a little historical research on the gamer's part.

The game is well suited to multiplayer games, each player handling one or more Warbands of anywhere from six to twenty or more figures on the table.  Game length is dependent upon the scenario design, from swift ship-to-ship fights to extended coastal raids or open-field battles.

The game is enhanced by the inclusion of a random events card deck which adds variety and surprises to play.

Unlike many sets of miniatures rules, Strandhogg can be enjoyed by players owning only a few dozen figures; an average Warband might number ten to twelve figures, and three Warbands compose a raiding force under a Noble.  The rulebook is sprinkled with sidebars featuring excerpts from the Norse Sagas for flavor, and also includes optional rules for special attributes or traits to individualize Leaders or leading warriors (for example, a warrior surnamed "the Stout" gains +1 on Defense; "Leg Biter" enjoys a +1 on Offense).

Players will often find themselves identifying strongly with the fortunes of their warband and even individuals within it; although Strandhogg is not a role-playing game, it deliberately strives to impart a strong flavor of its Viking focus.

Web address: STRANDHOGG@rochester.rr.com

Name: The Beautiful Game
Description:
The goal of The Beautiful Game is to collect a full side of 11 players and make it to the World Cup final.

As you progress in the game, your team will change.  Players may be booked on a red or yellow card.  Poor players may be sent to the bench until they improve.  Injuries?  You betcha!

There are many ways to gain or lose players.  Answering World Cup trivia, solving puzzles, and performing tasks are just some of the things you'll find yourself doing to improve your team.

Name: Snap Bowling
Description: Snap Bowling is a huge game by Ideal. The "alley" measures 40 inches long by 13 inches wide. The 10 pins have magnets in the bottom for easy setup.

Name: Scooby-Doo! Who Are You? Game
Description:
(from back of box)

Scooby-Doo and his friends are all dressed up in this fun and exciting guessing game. Each player gets their own game console with 24 different pictures on it. Secretly choose one of the characters - Chef Scooby-Doo, Baseball Daphne, Sombrero Velma, Bearded Shaggy, Fred with Glasses or any one of the other characters. On your turn, ask the other player a "Yes" or "No" question as you try to guess who they chose before they guess your card. As you get answers to your questions you'll start to figure out who your opponent picked. The first player to make a correct guess wins.

Name: Scarecrow Target Game
Description:
The original 1965 release comes in a very large 19" x 18" x 8" box.  It features a plastic scarecrow (which is almost as large as the box) with various scoring targets - hat (5 points), crows on arms (10 or 15 points) and a 50 point target on the scarecrow's coat which, when hit, causes the scarecrow's coat to fall off in pieces.  A dart gun with three suction-cup darts is also included.

A turn consists of firing all three darts at the scarecrow from a pre-agreed distance. If a player causes the coat of the scarecrow to fall off, 50 points is scored and their turn ends, regardless of the number of darts in reserve.

The first player to accumulate 300 points is the winner.

Game was re-released in 1975 in a very slightly different box.

Name: Open Sesame
Description: The Open Sesame Game is a game for up to four players. Spin the spinner and put 1, 2, or 3 jewels into the mountain. If the spinner lands on the Open Sesame space then each player quickly puts their marble into the mouth of the volcano. The first marble down the hole will open the door and spill the jewels.

Name: Four Over
Description: The Four Over Game claims to take the skill of pinball and the logic of checkers. Flip the steel ball to find out how many moves, then move your checkers across the board to the other player's home. The ball may knock some checkers out as it falls into the numbered slot.

Name: Hokie Golf
Description:
The object of Hokie Golf is the same a regular golf: end the game with the lowest score.  Everyone gets an initial hand of four cards, two of which are unknown.  Players then take turns drawing cards, discarding unwanted cards from their hand.  If you think you have the lowest score, you can pass your turn, ending the hole once everyone else gets one last draw.  Lowest score wins the hold.  Play nine holes for a short game, or eighteen for a full game.

Contains 111 Cards and Scoresheets.

Name: Die California Extrakarte
Description:
Postcard expansion to base game California by Michael Schacht published in 2006.


     Number 2 in the Abacusspiele / Spiele aus Timbuktu postcard-series


Also part of the expansion NEUE BONUSKARTEN.

Name: Sahara
Description:
Object of this game is to deliver 2 loads to the 2 oases and return to the staring point first.

The loads are carried by nice camels or dromedaries and movement depends on the number of loads as well as on the wind, which is determined with a roll of a spinner. The spinner is also responsible for determining how the sand dunes are shifting and if there are some Fata Morganas on the horizon.
 ( Fata Morganas are caused by hot and cold air which distorts the appearance of objects on the horizon either at sea or in the desert to make them look like, well, castles in the air.)


Additionally, there are some fixed desert fields on the board, but the main problem is, that when encountering such obstacles you need the use of water canisters. Each player has only 6 canisters and losing all of them means a restart or sometimes an elimination of the game.

Name: Nebraska
Description:
The deck has eight suits and 13 cards for each suit.
Players get ten cards at random and use them to bid (simultaneously) on a card revealed from the deck: the highest bid chooses if that card must be discarded (and everyone draws a card) or kept on the table. Then another card is revealed and bid upon. When five cards are on the table, each player scores accordingly to the five cards he still has in hand (due to matching suits and values with the cards on the table). 
The rulebook presents three scoring systems (one must be selected beforehand) to offer different levels of complexity.

Name: Nordi
Description:
The theme of this game is smuggling cigars, wine, rum, watches, cigarettes and money between Germany, Austria and Switzerland on skis! Thus, an unusual theme for the alps...

There are 3 home bases, where the players can buy up to 3 smuggling goods and start their way to deliver them to another base. Movements are not done by a dice roll, but the more goods a player is carrying, the slower will be his speed. this can be dangerous, because their is a fast moving frontier-guard, who will confiscate the goods, when he catches a player.

Before starting, the players should know, which smuggling goods give the best profit - watches are cheap to buy in Switzerland and give the most in Germany for example.

The game has double sided playing money, which comes in the (old) currencies of the 3 countries: Deutsche Mark, Schilling and Schweizer Franken.

Name: Play Racing
Description:
This is a sports car racing game with a variable board of 6 pieces and 4 movable chicanes.

Each player gets a board, where he indicates the speed, the additional gasoline and the brake reserves. The later two things are needed, when a player wants to reduce or amount his speed by more than 1 click on a 1-8 table.

There are also 2 small decks of cards, which are used for pit stops or when a car goes off the track. Some of the cards also influence the condition of the track, so racing gets even harder to master than it is anyway.

The game belongs to a series of 4 square cardboard games from Scandecor Play Racing, Play Olympic, Play Western, Play Pirates. It has funny comic drawings, which could easily be from Jean Jacques Loup, who has made many illustrations for puzzles.

Name: Play Olympic
Description:
This is a rather simple dice game, where 2-6 players play up to 17 sport events. It belongs to a series of 4 square cardboard games from Scandecor (Play Racing, Play Olympic, Play Western, Play Pirates).

All events are done with the roll of 1-3 dice and give 7-5-4-3-2-1 points for rank 1-7.

As with all games of the series, the board is illustrated with funny comics and the 6 plastic playing pieces are also made in that funny design.

Name: Play Western
Description:
Another game of the 4 square cardboard games from Scandecor (Play Racing, Play Olympic, Play Western, Play Pirates).

A railroad track crosses the longish board and a small train drives from left to right (and back if a longer play is wanted) with gold barrels in his wagon.

Each player has 2 desperadoes who must try to steal these gold barrels and bring them in his hideout. A turn consists of a roll of 2 dice, where one must be used for the movement of the train. Since the train must stop at all 5 stations spread around the board, it moves slow enough, that desperadoes of several players will meet it quite often and they can try to kill each other and take the gold barrel in this way.

As with all games of the series, the board is illustrated with funny comics.

Name: Play Pirates
Description:
Another game of the 4 square cardboard games from Scandecor (Play Racing, Play Olympic, Play Western, Play Pirates).

Before the game starts, several land pieces must be laid on the large gameboard, so you'll get a board with some islands and some fortified harbors.

Each player choses one home harbor, where his 4 ships start. Movement is done by dice roll, but it can be modified by some of the included cards.

12 of these cards indicate, where a treasure is located.   
The game ends, when all 12 treasures are found.

As with all games of the series, the board is illustrated with funny comics.

Name: Play Cavalry
Description:
This game belongs to a series of 4 games by Scandecor, who come in a square plastic box (Play Cavalry, Play Balance, Play Ecology and Play Numeric).

Play Ecology looks like a mixture of "Trap the Cap" and "Chess", but it is not as easy as that sounds. Each of the players has 6 playing pieces, which move like the Knights in chess. In the middle of the board is one neutral piece, who carries a wooden ball on his crater shaped top.

Object of the game is to catch that wooden ball (the playing pieces all have small craters on their top to put the ball on top) and bring it to your edge of the 9x9 game board. The neutral piece moves like the king in chess and it can make captures by jumping on other pieces - like in "Trap the Cap". What makes the game interesting is, that the neutral piece is the only piece that can capture normal pieces. That means, that you need at least 1 piece to capture the ball, but the other pieces can only try to block other pieces from doing so.

Name: Play Balance
Description:
This game belongs to a series of 4 games by Scandecor, which come in a square plastic board (Play Cavalry, Play Balance, Play Ecology and Play Numeric).

The board has 12x12 spaces and each of them is made as a 3d-hole, where you can place a tile looking to one player or to the other by tip over the tile.

One player plays with the 48 water tiles and the other takes the 48 land tiles. Each tile can be moved 1 space in advance. Captures (accomplished sideways) can be done when a tile can move to an empty space, which has an opponents tile directly adjacent to it. Since the tiles are facing in 2 directions, the rules use the term "overshadowed" for such tiles. The capture is done by tipping over the captured piece and if there are additional tiles directly behind the captured piece, you can tip over these tiles also.

The game ends, when all positions are blocked, that is when no reasonable moves can be made by neither player. You simply count the tiles then to see, if the water or land player has won the game.

Name: Play Ecology
Description:
This game belongs to a series of 4 games by Scandecor, which come in a square plastic board (Play Cavalry, Play Balance, Play Ecology and Play Numeric). )

The game is played on a 12x12 board. The game can be played with 2 or 4 players. Half of the players take the industrial pieces, the others the nature pieces. When 2 players play, each has the following 47 pieces: 
- 18 roads/rivers, 12 straight and 6 curved
- 24 houses/trees
-  4 factories/volcanoes
-  1 pollutions/earthquakes (disasters)

If playing with 4, each player gets half the pieces and the 2 additional pollution/earthquake tiles are used also.

The game begins with an empty board except the 2 or 4 disaster tiles, which are placed in the corners of the board. The players then start to place roads and rivers on the board and as soon as the first road/river is placed, they can also start to lay down the other pieces. Houses and factories can be placed 1-2 spaces besides the road, trees and volcanoes 1-2 spaces besides the river.

Factories/volcanoes protect the surrounding spaces from being overbuilt by the opponents. These restrictions make it more and more difficult to place the tiles on the board. Winner is the player/party who can lay down all their pieces.

Object of the game is to be the first, who can play all of their pieces.

Name: Play Numeric
Description:
This game belongs to a series of 4 games by Scandecor, which come in a square plastic board (Play Cavalry, Play Balance, Play Ecology and Play Numeric).

This game is played on a 12x12 board and each players has 9 dice as playing pieces. These dice look like normal 6-sided dice, but 2 sides of them are free. The are 2 types of dice, odd and even dice. Odd dice show 1-3-3-5 on their sides, even dice 2-4-4-6.

Object of the game is to win the most points, which are given for capturing opposing dice. You can also win points, when you succeed in bringing an own dice to the opposite corner of the board.

At the start, the 9 dice per player start in one corner of the board and they show 1,2,2,3,3,3,4,4,5 on top. When a die moves to an adjacent empty space, its value is not changed, but a die can also be used to jump over another, if the value on top is within a range of 1 to the jumping die. Then a die can be turned to change its initial value.

The game is rather slow developing, because it takes some time, until the dice approach each other on the large 12x12 board.

Name: Zehnkampf
Description:
Zehnkampf (=Decathlon) is a dice game with very short rules. All 10 Decathlon events are decided by simple dice rolls, but the rules for the running events are a little more confusing and require some work in order to understand them.

The results of the 10 events are scored just like a real Decathlon. The result of this is, that some events have bigger point ranges than others, so it would be better to make an extra effort in these events... but since it's a simple dice game, there is no room to make extra efforts.

Name: Pick a Peg
Description:
The game is played on a hex board, which has 97 holes. The board is placed upright on a plastic base and all 97 holes must be filled with 97 pegs. The pegs have to be placed so that both ends overhang the same length on both sides of the board.

Each player sits on one side of the vertical board and before starting, each must secretly hang his red playing piece on one of the 97 pegs.

Each turn, a player now takes off 1 peg off the board and he is free to turn the board by 60 degrees before taking a peg off.

The 2 playing pieces are formed like a horseshoe and if the opponent takes off a peg with a horseshoe hanging on it, it will fall down to the next peg - or on the table, if none is below. Winner is the player who succeeds in letting the opposing horseshoe fall on the table.

Name: Tesseract
Description:
This game has a 16x16 game board, but the playing pieces move on the 15x15 intersections.

The second and third row on each side of the board are the player's home sections, the space between is neutral. Each player has 6 "normal" playing pieces (1 tesseract, 1 cylinder, 1 pyramid, 1 rectangle, 2 stars), 2 large slide bars, 5 small slide bars and 2 crosses.

At the start, each player places the Tesseract, the pyramid, one star and 2 small slide bars in his section. Then the 2 crosses are placed in the neutral zone. These crosses cannot be moved and remain at their position until the end of the game. The remaining pieces: the cylinder, the rectangle, one star and 5 slide bars form the reserves.

Each turn, players now move their pieces over the board or place a piece from their reserves everywhere on the board. Object of the game is to either capture the opposing tesseract or capture all other "normal" pieces of the opponent.

The movements of the playing pieces different for every type. Interesting, that slide bars can capture normal pieces, but cannot be captured themselves.

Name: Der Millionär
Description:
The game is played within the box itself. The bottom has 30 slots to keep the available shares and 4 trays to save the money of the bank. The top cover can be left open and it indicates the current value and dividends for each title.

The game includes 5 shares numbered 1-5 in 6 different colors.

Players throw one 6-sided die and one color-die to determine which of the shares can be bought, pay dividends or maybe give special gratifications. If a 6 is thrown, the share of the thrown color is given a new value by an additional dice throw.

The game starts with 200.000 for each player and the one who collects  1 million first is the winner

Name: Elo Moussaillon
Description:
In this games players are maneuvering their fishing ship on a  mobile board circular which emulate currents and obstacle. The object of the game is to catch and sell a variety of fish of different market value.

Clearly positioned as a family game (and designed by the members of a single family), this French micro-edition is also an educational game trying to provide some insights about sea and the coastal fishing industry.

Name: Economy-Entscheidung-Erfolg
Description:
An interesting economic game, where players try to become the first player, who could buy and purchase 15-18 goods of 6 different types.

Several taxes and fees must be paid on the way to becoming the winner of the game. A few of them are fixed amounts, which must be paid when a player reaches a certain step on the way up, some must be paid, when a player misses a chance to buy or purchase goods and therefore has to draw 1 of 80 event cards.

There are six different goods available. A player can purchase 1-3 goods of a chosen type depending on a dice throw. Red goods can only be purchased by throwing a 6, green goods need at least a 5, yellow ones a 4 and so on.
All goods cost 10.000 per piece, but the selling price is higher for the harder goods, from 16.000 - 32.000.

Before selling, another dice throw is required, which needs matching  the throws while purchasing the goods.
 Last but not least, the purchase and sale of goods can be challenged by other players, if their  bid  was either lower or higher than the agreed on transaction.

Description:

     Das Lesezeichen der abgrundtiefen Scheußlichkeit!

     Das offizielle Lesezeichen der kraftvollen Bevollmächtigung
     Das offizielle Lesezeichen des himmelschreiend offensichtlichen Schummelns!
     Das offizielle Star Munchkin Lesezeichen des Clowntrooper-Chaos!
     Das offizielle Munchkin Fu Lesezeichen des Hong Kong Wrong
     Das offizielle Munchkin Fu Lesezeichen des erhabenen Scharfsinns
     Das offizielle Super Munchkin Lesezeichen des geflügelten Helms der Schnelligkeit
     Das offizielle MunchkinLesezeichen der glücklichen Wendung
     Das offizielle MunchkinLesezeichen der (fehlerhaften) völlig verbaselten Beschwörung
     Das offizielle #SpieltMunchkin Lesezeichen! @Pegasusspiele

Name: Benny Goodman Swings into a Game of Musical Information
Description:
"Benny Goodman Swings into a Game of Musical Information" is a Benny-Goodman-endorsed game which includes an 8-note metal xylophone with a wooden mallet, which is used for a music-guessing portion of the game, similar to Name That Tune.

One player acts as a "Music Professor" (a sort of host for the game), while the other players are his students.  The students are quizzed on their knowledge of popular songs and classical music.  Challenges include straight question-and-answer trivia, guessing songs from their chorus, and guessing songs which the professor plays on the xylophone.  The player with the highest score, based on number of correct answers, is the winner.

Name: The Monkees Game
Description:
"The Monkees Game", also known as "Hey Hey The Monkees Game", was a licensed game from Transogram (makers of many other 1960s licensed games) based on the popular NBC musical comedy series.

Players used pawns based on one of the four Monkees - Peter Tork, Davy Jones, Mike Nesmith, or Mickey Dolenz.  The board is designed to look like sheet music.  The element of chance is added by a spinner.  One unusual feature in some editions is a colorful six-note xylophone, with which players can make the Monkees theme tune, for which sheet music is included. Another edition includes a "four string" (two rubber band) plastic guitar along with the sheet music insert.

The box art is an illustration of the Monkees riding in a red GTO hot-rod convertible.

Name: Dough Re Mi
Description:
Based on the game show of the same name hosted by Gene Rayburn, which ran on NBC from 1958-60.

The game was played similarly to Name That Tune, but with only the first three notes of a popular song being played, and players then bid on their ability to guess the song correctly. The game cost more than the typical board game for the era due to including a small, eight-note xylophone which players used to begin each song.

Name: Team Work: Fußball 1
Description:
How's this supposed to work again? What happens when a team of two explainers are supposed to describe a concept but can only say the sentences together? But it gets better: the players can't discuss what they want to say ahead of time and must build the sentence while alternating words! A good time is guaranteed because the rest all try to figure out what the concept is at the same time. Who will have the most points?

This set of Team Work "Fußball 1" covers the topic soccer.

Expands:

    Team Work Original

Name: Team Work: Fußball 2
Description:
How's this supposed to work again? What happens when a team of two explainers are supposed to describe a concept but can only say the sentences together? But it gets better: the players can't discuss what they want to say ahead of time and must build the sentence while alternating words! A good time is guaranteed because the rest all try to figure out what the concept is at the same time. Who will have the most points?

This set of Team Work "Fußball 2" covers the topic soccer.

Expands:

    Team Work Original

Name: Asterix & Obelix: Die Lorbeeren des Caesar
Description:
'Explore Europe' (aka Europareise} meets 'Malefiz' - two (almost) classic German games combined to form an Asterix travel game across Europe. 
Players have to visit 5 locations before they can pick up Caesar’s laurels in Rome. Before they can deliver them to their village they have to visit another 5 locations. Blocking pieces simulate the 'evil Romans'.

Name: Earth Alert
Description:
Object: to be the first player to successfully reach all three EarthAlert Recycle Centers and earn a Unit of Oxygen at the final Recycle Center.

There are three types of cards needed to move around the board:

Question and Answer, in which a player must answer a true/false or multiple choice environmental question.

Definitions, in which player must define a geographical or environmental word or location.

Roleplay, in which player must guess what subject is being acted out by two other players. Example: One player must play the role of a pregnant woman, the other player is a taxi cab. The answer is "birth."

Each time a recycle center is entered, a recycle card is drawn with hints and suggestions on how to save the environment.

To answer any card incorrectly is to lose a Unit of Oxygen. But in the end, there is always the "Last Gasp" opportunity.

Name: Casino
Description:
2-6 players start with 18.500 gaming money and when the first player goes bankrupt, the game ends and the player with the most money wins the game.

Included in this game is 1 color-die and 6 dice in the colors shown on the color-die. There is also a paying board, which shows numbers from 4-20 and the corresponding payout amount.

Each turn consists of several dice throws, done by the "active" player. The inactive players can place fix bets (of 100) before each dice throw and all winning amounts are to be paid by the active player!

The dice throws are done by using the following procedure: the dice with the color showing on the color-die is placed on the paying board and it's number is added to the numbers of the dice already there.

Before the active player goes on throwing the remaining dice, the other players can retire and let them give the won amount from the active player. Fortunately, the active has also a winning option: when the color-die shows a color of a die already on the paying board, his turn end immediately and he collects all bets from the other players.

Name: Galopper-Glückswette
Description:
This is a horse racing game, where placing bets on the results is more important than the races themselves.

10 races are run with the help of 22 playing cards and each race has a fixed number of possible bets for a total of 21 bets. The amounts for these bets are also predefined, so that a player has exactly 21 different bet amounts for the whole game.

All bets must be placed before a race, so you depend heavily on luck, if you draw the best cards for your bets.

The races are funny to play. The cards have 2 colors on each side and cards must always match the color of the preceding one. One of the 22 cards marks the finishing line and the next 3 cards after that line give the running-in.

Name: Twist & Hold 'Em Poker Cube
Description:
From the packaging text:

"Twist & Hold 'Em Poker Cube features an entire deck of cards on one cube. Your 'hand' is the side that's facing you and the cards are 'shuffled' by turning the rows cube-style. Take anywhere for fun for the whole family!"

Pressman #1493 is basically a Rubik-style cube with stickers having playing card denominations on the faces. Also included are two six-sided dice. One of the dice lists a series of rotation instructions, and the other is the usual pip layout. Both dice have faces in six different colors that correspond to the centers of each face on the main card cube. The values of the central cube spaces increase by twos from 2 to Q (12) and progress through all four suits (hearts & spades are represented twice). The edge pieces are always two cards with a numerical difference of two and are always different in color. Similarly, the corner pieces progress in increments of two, half of them clockwise and half counterclockwise, and always two black and one red or two red and one black, with like colors never in matching suits. Rules for playing variants of Texas Hold 'Em, Black Jack, Vegas, Spades, Chicago Hi/Lo and Rummy are provided, but others could probably be adapted.

Name: Elimination 3
Description: A two player derivative of the Morris family of games, which can be played with partners.  The object of the game is to get three pegs in a row on either the solid or dotted lines.  Each time you do so, you get to remove an opponents piece.  The game ends when either you opponent concedes or has only two pegs left.

Name: Tooty Frooty: the New Mr. Potato Head Game
Description: Mr. Potato Head played Cootie style.  Each player selects a plastic head (potato, cucumber, orange or carrot), then spins the large spinner to determine what (if any) piece is added to their character.

Name: Victo
Description: The "New All-American Party Thriller!" from 1942...Victo is a WWII era Bingo game with quotes from American war heroes and leaders replacing the usual I-24.  Players are reminded on every card to "Buy U.S. War Bonds & Stamps."

Name: Jack And The Beanstalk
Description:
Mid-sixties Marvin Glass offering from Schaper for two players only.

The modular 'board' consists of a high quality hollow green plastic beanstalk about 18" high with a fluffy white cloud surrounding the top, concealing the 'sleeping' giant.  A sequence of ten small holes spirals from bottom to top of the beanstalk on each side.  Each of the holes is one of three shapes and these accommodate the stems of the plastic leaves players must insert in the correct sequence from bottom to top.

To start the game, all beanstalk leaves are placed inside the hollow beanstalk through a slot situated on each side.  There is a sliding apparatus at the base of the beanstalk which allows each player access to a single leaf on their turn.

The plastic beanstalk leaves come in 3 colors - green, gold & black.  The green leaves have stems that will only fit into specific beanstalk holes and must be replaced inside the beanstalk if they do not match the next in the sequence.  Gold leaves are universal and fit into any beanstalk hole.  Black leaves are useless and are immediately replaced through a slot.

The first player to complete the sequence of leaves in order wins the game.  When a leaf is placed in the final hole at the top of the beanstalk, a spring mechanism is triggered which causes the 'sleeping' giant to pop up.
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: Jack and the Beanstalk

Name: Season Harvest
Description:
Season Harvest is a resource-gathering game played on a modular board made of cards.  There are four card types: summer, fall, winter, and spring.  As you play cards to change the seasons in spaces on the board, seeds grow into trees which eventually bear fruit.  Your goal is to harvest as much fruit as possible and end the game with the most fruit in your basket.

Although the basic game is competitive, Season Harvest also has several cooperative variants.

http://www.invisible-city.com/play/292/season-harvest

Name: Minnesota Minutiae
Description: Minnesota Minutiae is a boxed deck of trivia cards, featuring the state of Minnesota.  Categories include music, politics, sports, geography and history.  No instructions or score-keeping bits are included, the cards may be designed as a replacement set for an existing trivia game.

Name: Total Play Football
Description:
From the website:

TOTAL PLAY FOOTBALL™ is a card game designed for non-stop action. Players able to recognize different Offensive card plays and make Defensive counter plays will certainly have the advantage. There is no turn for play in the Total Play Football Card Game. Any player can make a play for points or deny points at any time which adds even more fun and excitement to the game. For the love of the game called football and the advent of new technology, football can be played a myriad of ways. No one will feel excluded from playing Total Play Football™ because the game terminology does not require football lingo. All you need is the desire to win at an appealing and entertaining card game that is loads of fun for the whole family. The only way for you to know how well you will embrace the Total Play Football™ card game is to play it.

Name: 4th Quarter TouchDown Football
Description:
From the website:

4th Quarter Touchdown Football challenges your ability to work as teammates, while providing you with the entertainment of a board game. Set up as teams to challenge your opponents with fast action game play. By matching the game cards and moving down the field, your objective is to outscore your opponents before time runs out. Each player will lay their cards on the board and try to match, when a successful match is made the board is cleared and the attempt on an offensive advance is made for a second consecutive match. The yardage cards provided will move you forward for the quick score, or move you backward for loss yardages. But watch out for the turnovers, these cards could allow your opponents to score. Watch as the anticipation mounts as each passing card chooses the fate of your team and your record

Includes playing board, 64 playing cards, 40 home/away yardage cards, two game pieces, 100 score sheets, and a pencil.

Name: KootiKooti
Description:
KootiKooti is an addictive, strategic interactive game that is played with 2.5” flexible rubber game pieces. Using a finger to nudge or flip their KootiKooti, 2 to 4 players take turns, using their skill and judgment to try and ‘pin down’ their opponents KootiKooti to win the round.

Series 1 comprises 50 unique designed colorful game pieces for kids to collect and trade.

Name: Alpha Brik
Description: This abstract strategy game plays on 9x9 black and white board. Each players control 3 peons which can be displaced in straight line according to the result of a single dice roll. The object of the game is to capture bricks located on the center or bricks which have already been collected and placed at the opponent’s side, of the board and bring them back on his own side of the board. In addition to collection bricks, one's peons can be used to directly attack his opponent’s peons, with the effect of sending back the attacked peon in on his originating camp.

Name: The AAA Safe Driver Game
Description:
From the insert:

The object of this game is to be the first player to land on each of the six blue Safe Driver Stars by exact roll of 1 or 2 dice while traveling clockwise around the gameboard. Player draws the Safe Driver Card from the deck on gameboard which matches the Safe Driver Star on which he has landed. First player to reach HOME with all six different Safe Driver Cards wins the game.

Parts list: 1 gameboard and box with rules platform and plastic tray; 14 Violation cards; 4 AAA Membership cards; 4 sets of 6 Safe Driver Cards; 2 dice; 4 playing pieces; 1 returnable market research card; and approximately $850 play money.

- - - - - - - -

The market research card (return address: Interstate Games, 35 Morrison St. Manchester, NH 03104) asks if you enjoyed playing the game, found the directions easy to follow; learned more about AAA services, etc. It also asks how many times you played it and with what ages of players (10-15, 15-20, 20-50, and over 50). Box says for ages 8-80.

Anyway, I wonder how many surveys were returned to them.

Name: Das grosse essen & trinken Menü-Spiel
Description:
This game was available solely through the magazine "Essen & Trinken" (a magazine for cooking). 
You objective is it to get as many menus as possible. The menu always consist of 4 courses. You collect by drawing a card from a course of your choice. The card shows the kind of menu (classic, veg. etc.)and the value of that dish. You move forward as many spots as the value of the cards - depending on the place you finish you might have to answer a question or you can trade cards with other players.
At the end only finished menus are counted (and all menue cards have to be from the same kind).

All menu-cards contain a real recipe from the magazine, so you can actually use this game as a cook book (if you can understand German)

Name: All Change
Description:
All change is a tile placement word game that uses a turntable with 4 word slots. Players must place letters into the slot in front of them to make a 3 or 4 letter word.

The turntable is then rotated to present the players with one of the other words, one that their opponents have been working on, which they must add to, change or remove tiles from to make a new word.

Name: The New York City Trivia Game
Description:
The New York City Trivia Game is a fun way to learn about the people, places, events, geography, public transportation, museums, theaters, sports, stores, restaurants and media that make New York City so great.

NYTG will appeal to New York natives and one-time visitors alike. The City encompasses cultures and traditions the world over, so whether you play NYTG to test how much you already know or simply to learn more, you're sure to have a great time celebrating the diversity of New York City. [Excerpt from game introduction]

Move down the island of Manhattan, starting in Harlem and ending at the Statue of Liberty, answering questions in any one of four categories: Landmarks and History; Street Smarts; Arts, Entertainment and Sports; and Shopping, Eating and Media. NYTG will test and expand your knowledge about New York City. [Excerpt from game back of game box]

Name: Amelie, aufgepasst!
Description:
Help your 3 little ants find their way to their nest. Avoid the holes near the path where you can hide (get out of the game) from your enemies, which are mixed with good characters in some memory cards. So you have a good chance to stay on the right path.
A game which comes with rules in 8 languages (D,USA,F,E,P,J,NL,I)
